big_picture_notes: Titus is a pastoral letter in standard Hellenistic epistolary form: salutation (1:1–4), main didactic body (1:5–3:11), and conclusion (3:12–15). The core movement interweaves practical ethics with dense theological summaries, producing a chiastic feel: false teachers → household/communal ethics → grace/renewal rationale → civic conduct → warning against factious persons. Literary glue includes ‘sound doctrine’ vs false teaching, frequent ‘for/gar’ rationales, and the repeated emphasis on ‘good works’ as the fruit of God’s saving action (2:14; 3:1, 8, 14).

stories.story_title: The Commission and the Conflict in Crete
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Start (1:1) epistolary salutation opens; end (1:16) closes with the summary verdict on the opponents (‘they profess… deny by works’). Glue: commission→conflict motif linking Paul’s authority (1:1–4) to Titus’s task (1:5), bridged by elder qualifications (1:6–9) as antidote to false teachers (1:10–16).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Paul’s servant/apostle identity; hope of eternal life; grace and peace to Titus. Devices: appositional clauses, faith/knowledge/hope triad, epistolary form.

Left in Crete to set what remains and appoint elders; qualification list ends with ability to exhort in sound doctrine and refute gainsayers. Devices: positive/negative enumerations, purpose‑driven list.
Many insubordinate, empty talkers; rebuke sharply; Cretan proverb cited; verdict: profess but deny by works. Devices: polemic, quotation, contrast of profession vs practice.

stories.story_title: The Pattern of Sound Doctrine and Good Works
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Start (2:1) ‘But you—teach what accords with sound doctrine’ shifts to positive instruction; end (3:11) definitive handling of the divisive person. Glue: repeated ‘good works’ motif and didactic flow: household ethics → grace epiphany rationale → civic virtues → insistence and warning.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Addresses older men/women, younger women/men, Titus, slaves; purpose: adorn the doctrine of God our Savior. Devices: parallel addresses, propriety/self‑control emphasis, adornment telos.

For the grace of God appeared… training us as we await the blessed hope; concludes ‘declare these things… with all authority’. Devices: past‑present‑future salvation arc, trusted‑saying feel, authority frame.
Remind to submit, be gentle; once foolish, now saved by God’s kindness—renewal by the Spirit → heirs. Devices: vice‑then‑mercy contrast, soteriological summary (washing/renewal), heir motif.

scenes.scene_name: Insist on Good Works; Avoid Factions
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Trustworthy saying—insist on these for good works; avoid foolish controversies; warn a divisive person—self‑condemned. Devices: pedagogical insistence, controversy avoidance, disciplinary resolution.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Start (3:12) travel logistics and personal plans signal the close; end (3:15) final grace benediction. Glue: named coworkers, travel/greeting notes, and a last nudge toward good works in practical support.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Send Artemas/Tychicus; come to Nicopolis; speed Zenas and Apollos; learn to devote to good works; grace to all. Devices: logistical imperatives, good‑works refrain, epistolary benediction.
